pr_title: Implement with(), without(), withAll(), withoutAll() as default methods

timeline.author: motlin

replies.bodyText:
I tried to follow the same pattern suggested by Donald here
#822 (comment)
replies.author: aboullaite

replies.bodyText:
With these you can call super and return this

This was your suggestion in the linked comment @aboullaite pointed to above @motlin
replies.author: donraab

replies.bodyText:
@motlin @nikhilnanivadekar please share your opinions on this question.  I presented two options, and a third was proposed which I agreed with and posted what the resulting solution would look like here:
#822 (comment)
replies.author: donraab

replies.bodyText:
I find that every method which returns this delegates to another method and then returns this. They're pretty much always two lines. We can basically specify the implementation in Javadoc and have a consistent implementation everywhere. That's why I slightly prefer the implementation without super.
I realize this doesn't matter much and both implementations are fine. It's a slight preference. I'll go with whatever you'd like here.
replies.author: motlin
donraab

replies.bodyText: Good point. When I do work like this, I really do pull the methods up, using the IntelliJ refactoring. These methods aren't implemented in AbstractMutableCollection. If they were, I'd move them with the confidence that they are already covered. +1 these should be abstract on MutableCollection.
replies.author: motlin
aboullaite

replies.bodyText: @aboullaite Correct, minus the abstract as MutableCollection is an interface.
replies.author: donraab

timeline.bodyText: And these don't call super? I prefer these if I had to pick one, for consistency.
timeline.author: motlin

timeline.bodyText: Unfortunately, this is a breaking change. It's a good idea, it just has to wait for the next major version.
timeline.author: motlin

replies.bodyText: This needs to be reverted for minor version.
replies.author: nikhilnanivadekar

timeline.message: Implement with(), without(), withAll(), withoutAll() as default methods

Implement with(), without(), withAll(), withoutAll() as default methods

Signed-off-by: Mohammed Aboullaite <aboullaite.mohammed@gmail.com>

Implement with(), without(), withAll(), withoutAll() as default methods

Signed-off-by: Mohammed Aboullaite <aboullaite.mohammed@gmail.com>

timeline.bodyText:
@aboullaite I'd like to understand why was this javadoc removed. This indicates the behavior for a FixedSizedCollection is different than other MutableCollection instances. This is an awkward behavior here to be sure, but this is the unfortunate nature of something that is fixed in size.
I assume maybe these needed to be removed because they are now implemented as default methods and cannot be overridden with abstract. If that is the case, then can these be overridden with new default methods instead? I'll look at the current implementations and see if I can propose something.
timeline.author: donraab

replies.bodyText: @aboullaite Now that I have taken a look, please push this JavaDoc down to the implementation classes so it is not lost. The behavior is definitely different out of necessity. I will try and clean this up a bit after we merge your PR.
replies.author: donraab

replies.bodyText:
I disagree that the Javadoc should be pushed down. It's on an interface where it probably belongs, and the fact that it's abstract is good. Subclasses must have an interesting implementation. I'd suggest just revert the change to FixedSized* interfaces.
Good catch @donraab
replies.author: motlin

replies.bodyText: The only issue with this is that the implementations can't be left abstract because they are already defined as default methods in a parent interface. I'm fairly certain this won't compile. They could be overridden as default methods here to throw UnsupportedOperationException.
replies.author: donraab

replies.bodyText: Are we talking about in the interface (FixedSizeCollection) or in the concrete classes that implement it? It's ok to override a default interface method with an abstract interface method. And before we started FixedSizeCollection's methods were abstract, so I know the concrete classes implement these methods. I'm not understanding the problem here.
replies.author: motlin

replies.bodyText:
In the interface.

It's ok to override a default interface method with an abstract interface method.

My bad. I thought I remembered having an issue here overriding a default method with an abstract method in an interface. Just did some googling and this seems to be ok. If this isn't required then the FixedSizeCollection changes can just be reverted.
replies.author: donraab

replies.bodyText:
@donraab @motlin The compiler complains about having an abstract and a default method with matching signatures. The problem happens in FixedSizeSet and FixedSizeList since both MutableSet and FixedSizeCollection define  methods with(), without() ... and one is default and the other is abstract, the compiler requires the subinterface to explicitly declare which one it should inherit by overriding the methods again.
Should I override the methods in sub-interfaces (FixedSizeSet, FixedSizeList) , or remove the the abstract methods from FixedSizeCollection and push down javadoc documentation to implementation classes?
replies.author: aboullaite

timeline.bodyText: I think these should be default methods in MultiReaderBag.
timeline.author: donraab

replies.bodyText: @donraab why? To change the return type to MultiReaderBag? If so, that would be a good change, but one that has to happen in a major version. I think the minor version change looks good as-is, pulling these up to the MutableBag interface.
replies.author: motlin

replies.bodyText: Fair enough. I like the idea of returning MultiReaderBag though so access to the multi-reader specific API is retained.
replies.author: donraab

replies.bodyText:
I started this change just now in #879
Once this PR lands, I can add the new methods too.
replies.author: motlin

timeline.bodyText: I think these should be default methods in MultiReaderList.
timeline.author: donraab

replies.bodyText: Same comment. Presumably MultiReaderSet too?
replies.author: motlin

replies.bodyText: Yes
replies.author: donraab

timeline.bodyText: I'm wondering, can without and withoutAll return FixedSize*?
timeline.author: motlin

replies.author: aboullaite
motlin

replies.bodyText: Anyway, this change can't be made in a minor version, so I think we're ready to land this change as-is.
replies.author: motlin

replies.bodyText: Yes, in that cyaee, the same changes needs to be made in every class that implements FixedSize*! Is this something of interest? I can introduce all the discussions captured here in another PR
replies.author: aboullaite

replies.bodyText: @aboullaite Don't make those changes yet.  Leave them as is for now.  We can fix this during a major release.
replies.author: donraab

replies.bodyText: @aboullaite Yes you can do this in a separate PR, but it will have to wait for a major release.
replies.author: donraab
